text: think so
Does anyone knows how Telegram group invitation works? I mean when user clicks a group hyperlink, it opens up the app?
<@U0Z1T72VC|thanhpn91> has joined the channel
<@U0Z2BJ550|quangtm> has joined the channel
<@U0Z248CVB|vaklinzi> has joined the channel
You can register an intent-filter on a URL

```
<data
    android:host="something.example.com"
    android:scheme="https" />
```
<@U0Z25B2S1|eltjov> has joined the channel
<@U04TK850N>: thanks. i just knew it is called app deep linking :stuck_out_tongue:
<@U053PPGDC>: it was the nested generics that caused the problem apparently
Some1 from JB suggested I change MvpComponent to `interface MvpComponent<V : MvpView, out P : MvpPresenter<V>>`
<@U0Z2LA9AM|vourkosa> has joined the channel

<@U0K1ALDQE>: I would suggest to create your own mvp, it's easier and faster and you won't need all these generics. In fact, my base activity is just this `public abstract class BaseActivity extends AppCompatActivity`and my base presenter is this `public class BasePresenter<V extends PresentationView>` where `PresentationView` is just a marker interface. This is a good one <https://github.com/android10/Android-CleanArchitecture>

attachments.text: Android-CleanArchitecture - This is a sample app that is part of a series of blog posts I have written about how to architect an android application using Uncle Bob's clean architecture approach.

text: I was planning to so when I had more time
Does App Invites support anything else other than email and sms for now?
agree with <@U09T8SFG8>
<@U0K1ALDQE>: to me it honestly seems less time to rollout your own
I was used to working with Mosby in java because that’s what I was introduced to at my first android job
That’s why I thought trying to use it for kotlin 2.
Are you using it now for your own side project, a new work project or the same work project?
the code from before I mean
I’m just toying around.
if you are toying around then I would definitely say to go with your own
It’s not for work. And I’ll write my own MVP implementation later on
I came across a few things I don’t like in mosby. And I’m trying to figure out how I want to approach it
The thing is that you won't really write your own MVP implementation, you will barely need to write anything
How do you guys handle lifecycle?
MVP is extremely simple
I don't have lifecycle methods in my presenters
And your view? attaches in onCreate/onDestroy?

I specify everything in actions. For example if I want when my activity first starts to load a list of items from the network, at the bottom of my activity's onCreate I don't have `presenter.onCreate()` but I have `presenter.loadItems()`
Yeah, I do the same thing
Presenter should be lifeless and android package free imo
agreed
Currently I added something to mosby, where I inject an Util which tells me if my app went through onStop or onResume to prevent fragments from crashing (in the off chance I use them)
Which I can easily mock in tests
And I attach the view in onCreate/onDestroy
So the presenter should life through a configuration change 2
<@U0Z37HDNE|babicheva> has joined the channel

word, when these MVP “frameworks" started coming out I didn’t see much sense in them. And then just yesterday, after a friend told me their agency tried to use the Mosby and Nucleus in a few projects and decided it’s a mistake and they should just roll out their own.
Can either of you share how you do it? Perhaps for some good inspiration :simple_smile:
I’ll hopefully have a great sample app by the end of the month that I’m doing for some competition so I’ll open it up
<@U0548MM6B> :taco:
there is an old one on my github, but that’s like from a year ago or something, with dagger 2 alpha and no rx and some things I’d punch myself if I saw now

Yeah me too, I am working on an app with in-memory caching, disk caching, databases, network, RxJava, MVP, Dagger 2 and all that but I still haven't finished. It's on GitHub but I have it private until I finish it
but in any case the repo that I sent you is very good
hmm okay
Thanks both! I’m looking forward to seeing both :simple_smile:
there was a list with repos like that but I cant seem to find it
One more question: What do you guys do for the issue I mentioned before
The illegalStateExcpetion after onSaveInstance thingy
there is also <https://github.com/artem-zinnatullin/qualitymatters> from <@U091EBYSU>
IllegalStateException?
Currently I added something to mosby, where I inject an Util which tells me if my app went through onStop or onResume to prevent fragments from crashing (in the off chance I use them)
Basically it’s a util that registers on application lifecycle, and exposes it by an interface `fun isInBackground() : Boolean`
you can find and check out Helpee on github, but it’s about a year old with lousy code cuz it was rushed in a week’s worth time
you could have a `isAlive()` method for your fragments which is done in the repo I mentioned above
<https://github.com/artem-zinnatullin/qualitymatters/blob/master/app/src/main/java/com/artemzin/qualitymatters/ui/fragments/BaseFragment.java>
Yeah, `isAlive()` is probably something similar to what I did
oooh like his runOnUiThreadIfFragmentAlive

He has all the main thread logic inside the views. I personally prefer to do that in my presenter because my Presentation layer (Presenter-View) does barely anything and always runs on the main thread
as I see only thing he does in the views is stuff like managing visibility
yes, the presenters are running on a background thread (<http://Schedulers.io|Schedulers.io>())
oh, I see now
he doesn't use RxAndroid's main thread, but a MainLooper handler in the views
mine run on main, I just use .observeOn(androidScheduler) where androidScheduler is injected as a dependency
I do the same thing
But if between onStop and onDestroy you would call something on the view that is not allowed after savedInstance you get an exception
yes I do the same as well
How do you take care of that?
tho I see the use of this, in some complicated logic where it takes a second on two this would be really useful not to muddle your presenter with RxAndroid
in general I go like this: Data Layer -> io scheduler, Domain Layer -> computation scheduler, Presentation layer -> android scheduler
<@U0K1ALDQE>: I don't remember having that problem :confused:
in that case, fragment isFinishing should return true
or “isAlive” should return false
and the view in your presenter will be null
But i’m launching the fragment
you’re launching it in between onStop and onDestroy? :thinking_face:
I came across that issue a while back
View (activity) -> attach/detach onCreate/onDestroy
Presenter is uploading some files, when error occurs show dialog when finished launch other activity
do you have your presenter bound to your activity?
If error occured while activity went in back it crashed ( It was a DialogFragment :no_mouth::gun:)
If it finished while in back, the activity got launched while I was in other apps X.X
presenter didn’t unbind?
only does between onCreate and onDestroy
So would you guys suggest doing so between onResume and onStop?
What I did was have a isViewAttached method in my presenter, which checked if view was attached AND if app didn’t go in background
it was either that, or checking in the view but I didn’t want my code to get stuffed with if-checks
I think you can’t avoid that if inside the view in that case
you should be detaching your presenter in onDestroy
yeha, but onDestroy isn’t called in this case yet
and then your view methods won't be launched at all
But my app is in background
so onDestroy is not called
so in that case the view method is called and app crashes
Oh I see now
And also launching an activity after onStop was not something that felt nice / looked good ><
I would have the checking logic in the view
`if(isGoingToBlowUp()) return;`
Hm, yeah if I implement my own MVP I can move isViewAttached to view instead of presenter
Something I’ll have to think about
But so you guys agree on onCreate/onDestroy + checking on if it’s after savedInstance for critical stuff?

I am personally thinking in terms of: "What would happened if I used this presenter with a custom view instead of what I have". So I end up at: "It's the view's responsibility to know if it's in a non-blowing-up state"

hehe that happens to me when I fuck something up on our main screen :grin: 
my crash handler just restarts from the splash (if the crash was on home) so then if I switch the app after it crashed or force close it after intent fired already, I get the activity suddenly launched again :smile:
I don’t like executing view code after onPause anyway but still
I’m very unclear on the whole custom view story
view should do the unbinding imo, since it’s is the element with the lifecycle
The custom view was an example, what I'm trying to say is to think this in terms of reusability
I like that argument <@U0548MM6B>
Yeah, I agree with you both
I just needed some clarity in my head
tho I don’t think custom view, I think “if I moved this to Swing or JavaFX or something else, will it still work?” :smile:
Upvotes everywhere
haha :smile:
But <@U0548MM6B> you also get a hammer for reminding me of Swing
:smile:
Hmm. I’m convinced that I need to move away from mosby now :smile:
very enlightening conversation
Thanks <@U0548MM6B> :taco:
<@U09T8SFG8>: :taco:

To be fair Mosby is really cool and it is fairly well designed. The problem is that it tries to encapsulate a design pattern that is very important in data-driven applications. Learning the ins and outs of that pattern by yourself will help immensely in designing your presentation layer better and with having more flexibility. In general, I would avoid any library encapsulating a software design pattern that I would have to use again and again.
I’ll let you know if I have a demo app or something ready
:wink:
Any downsides to letting presenters be single instance? Injected through dagger and destroyed when activity finishes
you’ll inevitably forget to destroy them and end with either npes or memory leaks everywhere
we tried, and failed
Haven’t had that issue.
But I see what you mean.. It’s another thing to keep track off.
yeah I suppose a proper framework is better at that
Another MVP framework, this time made in Kotlin, for Kotlin, by Kotlin with bonus sexy girls sample app <https://github.com/nekocode/kotgo>

text: Oh the asian libs :heart:

Hey guys, today I updated to Android studio 2 and Android SDK tools to 25.1.1. Now Google maps is not loading and the error is:
```Authorization failure.  Please see <https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android/start> for how to correctly set up the map.
04-08 14:45:06.097 24504-25056/bg.web3.takeforfree E/Google Maps Android API: In the Google Developer Console (<https://console.developers.google.com>)
                                                                              Ensure that the "Google Maps Android API v2" is enabled.
                                                                              Ensure that the following Android Key exists:```
Everything in the Google developer console is filled correctly because my colleague is able to load the map but she is using sdk 24.4.1. What I should do in this case?
make sure you have the right debug key SHA on API console added
It seem not be the android studio update issue.
I am now updating mine as well lets see...
I've updated my AS, and my google map project works as usual. (The same version of dependencies)
Authorization failure error is definately not bcoz of AS, may be the Key SHA changed if you have installed a fresh
I generated a new one and I will test to see whether there is any change
Make sure to wait a while, it takes some time for google to update the new key.
guys, it works
:simple_smile: Thank you
